prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ID 141: [NII] 205um line observation
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to detect the [NII] 1461.GHz line, which is redshifted to a frequency of 278.682 GHz, in ALMA Band 7, with a beam size of 1", to reach a detection of S/N > 5 over a velocity channel of 100 km/s.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use one baseband for our targeted [NII] line, and the other 3 basebands for continuum measurements.
We used the lowest spectral resolution and widest frequency coverage per baseband. This was driven by our our scientific goal of detecting the total line flux in the most efficient way and at the same time, maximizxing the sensitivity for the continuum measurement.

Since we are primarily targeting at the line flux of the source and the source size is on the order of 1", we therefore simply choose beam size = 1" and conservatively set the largest angular scale at 2" for the source.

Our sensitivity calculation and desired S/N ratio are as follows: (1) The expected flux of the targeted [NII] 1461.13 GHz line = 8.15 Jy*km/s. (based on the source IR and measured [CII] 158um fluxes, as detailed in the proposal text.) (2) The FWHM of the measured [CII] 158um line = 690 km/s. (3) Dividing (2) into (1) gives the mean flux density of the targeted [NII] line = 11.82 mJy. (4) The sourxe size is on the order of our chosen ALMA beam of 1", so the mean line flux flux density per beam = 11.82 mJy/beam. (5) Since we are primarily targeting at the line flux, we ask for detceting this mean line flux density per beam at S/N = 5 per beam averaged over a velocity channel of 100 km/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BR 1202-0725: [NII] 205um line observation
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Our science goal is to detect the [NII] 1461.GHz line in both galaxies in this pair system at z = 4.693 in ALMA Band 6, with a beam size of 1", to reach a detection of S/N > 5 over a velocity channel of 100 km/s. This target consists of a pair of galaxies at the same redshift, but separated by 3.8 arcsec. The two galaxies can be observed in the same ALMA field of view. We simply point the observation at the middle position of this pair.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use one baseband for our targeted [NII] line, and the other 3 basebands for continuum measurements.
We used the lowest spectral resolution and widest frequency coverage per baseband. This was driven by our our scientific goal of detecting the total line flux in the most efficient way and at the same time, maximizxing the sensitivity for the continuum measurement.

Since we are primarily targeting at the line flux of the source and the source size is on the order of 1", we therefore simply choose beam size = 1" and conservatively set the largest angular scale at 2" for the source.

Our sensitivity calculation and desired S/N ratio is based on the fainter galaxy (i.e., the southern galaxy) in the pair and is as follows: (1) The expected flux of the targeted [NII] 1461.13 GHz line = 0.45 Jy*km/s. (based on the source IR and measured [CII] 158um fluxes, as detailed in the proposal text.) (2) The FWHM of the measured [CII] 158um line = 328 km/s. (3) Dividing (2) into (1) gives the mean flux density of the targeted [NII] line = 1.37 mJy. (4) The sourxe size is on the order of our chosen ALMA beam of 1", so the mean line flux flux density per beam = 1.37 mJy/beam. (5) Since we are primarily targeting at the line flux, we ask for detecting this mean line flux density per beam at S/N = 5 per averaged over a velocity channel of 100 km/s.

(based on the source IR and measured [CII] 158um fluxes, as detailed in the proposal text.) (2) The FWHM of the measured [CII] 158um line = 340 km/s. (3) Dividing (2) into (1) gives the mean flux density of the targeted [NII] line = 5.42 mJy. (4) The sourxe size is on the order of our chosen ALMA beam of 1", so the mean line flux flux density per beam = 5.42 mJy/beam. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a spectral-line "snapshot" program with ALMA to obtain (a) the [NII] 205 um line fluxes of 7 galaxies and the CO(7-6) line fluxes of 5 galaxies to complete the [NII] and CO(7-6) data for a sample of 8 luminous galaxies at z = 4 to 5, and (b) the [NII] 205 um line fluxes of 4 L*-class galaxies at z ~ 5.5, with sub-solar metallicities. The [CII] 158 um line fluxes are available for all these galaxies. The data set of (a) will be used to validate, up to z = 5, a method of using (i) the CO(7-6) line luminosity as an accurate and robust star formation rate (SFR) measure and (ii) the [NII]/CO(7-6) (or [CII]/CO(7-6)) flux ratio as a useful estimator of the far-infrared (FIR) color (thus, the dust temperature or SFR surface density). The [NII] data of (b) would represent the first detections of this line in L* galaxies at z > 5, and will be used with the [CII] data to quantitatively constrain the FIR colors of these galaxies and provide an independent assessment of their metallicities. The outcome of this porposal will lay the ground work for using this simple spectral line method to survey or study the SFRs of high-z galaxies in the coming ALMA era.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
